section.title: Composition with Inverse Trigonometric Functions
section.p:
In the exercise set of Section 3 we investigated some examples that involved composition of inverse trigonometric functions. For instance, we found that \sin\left(\sin^{-1} 0.9 \right)=0.9 and that \sin^{-1}\left(\sin 2 \right)=1.1416
These examples show that if f(x)=\sin x and g(x)=\sin^{-1} x, then for some values of x it is true that their composition produces the original x-value. However, for other x-values their composition does not produce the original x-value.

statement.p: Let f(x)=\sin x and let g(x)=\sin^{-1} x. For what values of x is it true that f(g(x))=\sin \left(\sin^{-1} x \right)=x? For what values of x is it true that g(f(x))=\sin^{-1} \left(\sin x \right)=x? Explain the results.

solution.p: The graphs in show y=\sin \left(\sin^{-1} x \right) on the left and y=\sin^{-1}\left(\sin x \right) on the right. The graph of f(g(x))=\sin \left(\sin^{-1} x \right) is identical to the graph of y=x on the interval [-1,1]. The graph of g(f(x))=\sin^{-1} \left(\sin x \right) is identical to the graph of y=x on the interval \left[-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2} \right]. Therefore, \sin \left(\sin^{-} x \right)=x for all x between -1 and 1 and \sin^{-1} \left(\sin x \right)=x for all x between -\frac{\pi}{2} and \frac{\pi}{2}.

figure.caption: Graphs of y=\sin \left(\sin^{-1} x \right) and y=\sin^{-1}\left(\sin x \right)

solution.p: To explain why \sin \left(\sin^{-1} x \right)=x only on the interval [-1,1]] we must consider the domain of the composition f(g(x))=\sin \left(\sin^{-1} x \right). The domain of f \circ g is the subset of the domain of g(x)=\sin^{-1} x for which the values g(x) are in the domain of f(x)=\sin x. The domain of g is -1 \le x \le 1. The values g(x) are always between -\frac{\pi}{2} and \frac{\pi}{2}; since the domain of f is all real numbers, all values of g are in the domain of f. Therefore, the domain of f \circ g is equal to the entire domain of g, which is -1 \le x \le 1. Therefore, \sin \left(\sin^{-1} x \right)=x for all values of x in the domain of the composition, that is, for all x between -1 and 1, inclusive.

To explain why \sin^{-1} \left(\sin x \right)=x only on the interval \left[-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2} \right] we must consider the range of g(f(x))=\sin^{-1} \left(\sin x \right). The values of g(f(x)) are in the range of g(x)=\sin^{-1} x, which is between -\frac{\pi}{2} and \frac{\pi}{2}. If \sin^{-1}\left(\sin x\right)=x is equal to x, the value of x must also be in the interval from -\frac{\pi}{2} to \frac{\pi}{2}, inclusive. Therefore, \sin^{-1}\left(\sin x\right)=x for all x between -\frac{\pi}{2} and \frac{\pi}{2}.

Note that \sin\left(\sin^{-1} x\right)=x is equal to x on its entire domain, which is -1 \le x \le 1. In contrast, \sin^{-1} \left(\sin x \right)is equal to x only when -\frac{\pi}{2} \le x \le \frac{\pi}{2}, even though its domain is all real numbers.

subsection.title: Class Practice

ol.li: Determine the values of a for which \cos\left(\cos^{-1} a \right)=a. Explain your results.
Determine the values of a for which \cos^{-1} \left(\cos a \right)=a. Explain your results.
Determine the values of a for which \tan\left(\tan^{-1} a \right)=a. Explain your results.
Determine the values of a for which \tan^{-1} \left(\tan a \right)=a. Explain your results.

Comment on the statement “The composition of a function and its inverse yields the identity function.”. Is this statement always true? Under what conditions, if any, might it be false? Is there a clarification or restriction that can be added to the statement so that it is always true?

subsection.p: As you know, functions that are not inverses can also be composed. For these kinds of compositions, we need to recall that inverse trigonometric functions produce numbers that are arc lengths or angle measures. Therefore, it will sometimes be convenient to use our understanding of right triangle trigonometry to evaluate these compositions.

solution.p: We want to find the sine of a number whose cosine is \frac{3}{8}. If we use our calculator to approximate \cos^{-1}\left(\frac{3}{8} \right) and then take the sine of that value, our result will be an approximation rather than exact answer. Therefore, we will use our knowledge of right triangle trigonometry to evaluate this expression

If we let \theta represent \cos^{-1} \left(\frac{3}{8} \right), then \theta is the number between 0 and \pi whose cosine is \frac{3}{8}. The value we want to find can be written as \sin \theta. The triangle shown in will help us find the sine of \theta without first finding \theta. Since the cosine of \theta is defined as the ratio of the length of the adjacent side to the length of the hypotenuse, the length of the side adjacent to \theta and the length of the hypotenuse are in the ratio 3:8.
\theta=\cos^{-1}\left(\frac{3}{8} \right)in a right triangle
Using the Pythagorean Theorem, the side opposite \theta has length \sqrt{8^2-3^2}=\sqrt 55. This means that the sine of \theta, defined as the ratio of the length of the opposite side to the length of the hypotenuse, is equal to \frac{\sqrt 55}{8}. Since \theta is between 0 and \pi and has a positive cosine, we know that \theta is in the first quadrant and therefore has a positive sine.

If in we had been asked to find \sin \left(\cos^{-1} \left(\frac{3}{8} \right) \right), we would have again found \sin \theta = \pm \frac{\sqrt 55}{8}. Since \cos \theta = -\frac{3}{8} and the range of the inverse cosine function is [0, \pi], we know \theta is in the second quadrant. In te second quadrant \sin \theta is positive, and we again choose \frac{\sqrt 55}{8} for the answer.

statement.p: Express \tan \left(\cos^{-1} \left(x+1 \right) \right) in terms of x without trigonometric functions.

solution.p: The expression \tan \left(\cos^{-1} \left(x+1 \right) \right) represents the tangent of an angle \theta whose cosine is x+1 . The technique of can be used here with slight adaptation. Let \theta=\cos^{-1}\left(x+1 \right). We do not know whether x+1 is positive or negative, so we must consider two possible positions for angle \theta; the angle can be in either the first or second quadrant, since the range of inverse cosine is [0, \pi]. Draw \theta in the unit circle with its vertex at the origin, and draw a right triangle with one side on the x-axis. (see ).

Since \cos \theta = x+1 and the question asks for \tan \theta, first find \sin \theta. Since 0 \le \theta \le \pi, \sin \theta will be non-negative. Using either the Pythagorean Theorem or the identity \sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = 1 , the value of \sin \theta is \sqrt{1^2-\left(x+1 \right)^2}, which can be written as \sqrt{-x^2-2x}. The tangent of \theta is the ratio of \sin \theta to \cos \theta, so \tan \left(\cos^{-1} \left(x+1 \right) \right)=\frac{\sqrt{-x^2-2x}}{x+1}. Note that the tangent will be positive if x+1 is positive (\theta in the first quadrant) and will be negative if x+1 is negative (\theta in the second quadrant).

ol.li: Substitute x=-\frac{1}{2} in \tan \left(\cos^{-1} \left(x+1 \right) \right) and in \frac{\sqrt{-x^2-2x}}{x+1}. Compare the results.
Substitute x=\frac{1}{2} in \tan \left(\cos^{-1} \left(x+1 \right) \right) and in \frac{\sqrt{-x^2-2x}}{x+1}. Compare the results.

solution.p: The expression \sin^{-1} \left(2x \right) represents an angle whose sine is 2x. Similarly, the expression \cos^{-1} x represents an angle whose cosine is x. The equation \sin^{-1} \left(2x \right)=\cos^{-1}x means that these two angles are equal. Therefore, there is an angle \theta whose sine is 2x and whose cosine is x. The angle \theta must be in the interval \left[0,\frac{\pi}{2} \right] because it is in the range of the inverse sine function, which is \left[-\frac{\pi}{2},\frac{\pi}{2} \right], and also in the range of the inverse cosine function, which is \left[0,\pi \right]. Since \sin \theta =2x, \cos \theta =x, and \sin^2 \theta+\cos^2 \theta=1, we know that \left(2x \right)^2+x^2=1.

An alternate way to solve \sin^{-1} \left(2x \right)=\cos^{-1}x is by “undoing” one of the inverse trigonometric functions to isolate one of the variables. This “undoing” can be accomplished by composing a function with its inverse. We choose to take the sine of both sides of the equation. This “undoes” the inverse sine function as follows:
\sin \left(\sin^{-1} \left(2x \right) \right) \amp = \sin\left(\cos^-{1} x \right) 2x \amp = \sin\left(\cos^-{1} x \right)
Note the the expression \sin\left(\cos^-{1} x \right) is undefined for some values of x, such as, x \gt \frac{1}{2} or x \lt -\frac{1}{2}. However, if we assume that x is a number for which \sin^{-1} \left(2x \right) is defined, then we can be sure that \sin \left(\sin^{-1} \left(2x \right) \right)=2x.

We can use the technique of to find the sine of an angle \theta whose cosine is x.
Right triangle illustrating \theta=\cos^{-1}x
Since the range of \cos^{-1}x is \left[0, \pi \right], the sine of \cos^{-1}x is positive. Using the triangle shown in , we see that \sin \left(\cos^-{1} x \right)=\sqrt{1-x^2}.

statement.p: Find the exact value of each of the following.
Find the domain and range of the function f(x)=\sin \left(\cos^{-1} x \right).
Sketch and label a unit circle to illustrate the fact that \sin^{-1} \left(\cos 2.3 \right)=-0.7292.

A picture of height 3 feet is placed on a wall with the bottom of the picture 4 feet above the eye level of an observer. Write a function that expresses the angle \theta subtended at the observer's eye in terms of the distance x between the observer and the wall . Find the distance x that maximizes the subtended angle. This distance will provide the best viewing angle for the observer.
Angle subtended by a picture

Sketch a graph of each function, giving special attention to the domain and range.
y=\cos \left(\cos^{-1} x \right)
y=\cos^{-1} \left(\cos x \right)
y=\tan \left(\tan^{-1} x \right)
y=\tan^{-1} \left(\tan x \right)
For some values of x, \sin^{-1} \left(\sin x \right) \ne x. For these x-values, what is the value of \sin^{-1} \left(\sin x \right)? Explain why your answer is reasonable.
For some values of x, \cos^{-1} \left(\cos x \right) \ne x. For these x-values, what is the value of \cos^{-1} \left(\cos x \right)? Explain why your answer is reasonable.

Rewrite each of the following expressions without trigonometric functions. State any necessary restrictions on the value of the variable.
\sin \left(\cos^{-1} x \right)
\cos \left(\tan^{-1} x \right)
\sin \left(\cos^{-1} + \sin^{-1} \right)
\tan \left(\cos^{-1} \left(-\frac{1}{x-1} \right) \right)

A solar receptor is placed at ground level between two buildings whose heights are 115 meters and 70 meters, respectively . The buildings are 100 meters apart. The angle \theta is the angle swept out by the sun at the receptor between the time it appears over the top of the taller building and the time it disappears behind the smaller building. For the greatest efficiency, the receptor should be located where it receives the most sunlight, in other words, where \theta is a maximum. Write a function that expresses the angle \theta in terms of the distance x between the receptor and the taller building. Then determine the most effective location for the receptor.
Location of a solar receptor

ASolve each equation.
\cos^{-1} \left(2x \right)=\sin^{-1} x
\cos^{-1} \left(3x-1 \right)=\sin^{-1} x
\sin^{-1} \left(2x \right)= \pi + \cos^{-1} x
